awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Ongoing Training, Evaluation, and Tracking of Program Impact
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this award is to support the goals of the NSF I-Corps program to increase the economic and societal impact of NSF research funding directly, through enabling commercialization of research, and indirectly, by equipping scientists and engineers with skills and experience in developing and testing economically scalable models for the development of a product or technology. The structured, repeatable program that has been developed engages a national community of institutions and faculty to deliver the training and support these outcomes. Through the work proposed here, this project supports the training of more than 500 additional participants, supports the training of additional faculty to increase the diversity of the faculty pool and maintain fidelity of the program pedagogy, continues conducting systematic data collection and tracking of teams immediately before and long after formal participation in the program, and creates and disseminates datasets of use to both novice and experienced researchers in the field as well as the dissemination of scalable systems for impact measurement that provide both a framework that can be adopted by others in the field.  The systems created through this work, and the insights gained, will advance the understanding of how best to track venture outcomes and assess the impact of early-stage entrepreneurial support programming.

This NSF project will support the evaluation of I-Corps program outcomes and tracking of program impact in a systematic and timely way.  This work is important to the operation of a consistent, high-fidelity program at scale and to the measurement of long term program results and an understanding of what works. The core intellectual merit of this work is insight into the program's impact, both economic outcomes and participants' career and research outcomes, over time. To gain this insight, the project evaluates the delivery of each cohort, administers a longitudinal outcomes survey, and tracks venture outcomes independently to verify program impact data. Working with NSF, the project makes these datasets accessible to the research community to enable the continued study of how best to support emerging science and technology innovation. The processes and data systems that efficiently track outcomes and provide insights into the development of technology-based products and ventures are a product of this project, as well.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: National Collegiate Inventors and Innovators Alliance
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: NATIONAL COLLEGIATE INVENTORS & INNOVATORS ALLIANCE, INC.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: National Collegiate Inventors and Innovators Alliance

por.por_cntn:
VentureWell began work with the National Science Foundation (NSF) in 2011 to develop an intensive lean startup training for academic researchers and students. The Innovation Corps (I-CorpsTM) course teaches these researchers how to evaluate the commercial potential of their innovations and develop a business model based on data gathered through customer discovery. The I-Corps program increases the economic and societal impact of NSF research funding directly, through commercialization of research, and indirectly, by equipping scientists and engineers with skills and experience in developing and testing economically scalable models for the development of a product or technology.

VentureWell serves as the implementing and evaluation partner for the I-Corps program, supporting its growth into a national initiative that, as of the end of this award (IIP-1832730), has trained over 7,300 innovators in more than 2,200 teams. Through our work with NSF on the I-Corps program, we have created a streamlined, repeatable process that has been successfully scaled to 14 cohorts per year over the past eight years, totalling 104 courses. This grant covers a three-year period, during which time 1,979 individuals completed the program. VentureWell's execution and oversight of the program has ensured fidelity to the curriculum, consistently high-quality instruction and coaching, and seamless course management.

To best evaluate program progress and results, VentureWell tracks economic and societal outcomes of the course through surveys administered pre- and post-course, and at two separate time points after program completion, as well as through proprietary databases and tracking of published federal awards. Using this data, we find clear economic and societal benefits of the I-Corps program. Since the program's inception, I-Corps teams have formed 1,267 companies that have attracted more than $1B in follow-on investment and grants. These companies operate in a broad range of sectors including health, energy, materials, agriculture, and information technology, and are geographically distributed across 49 states, DC and Puerto Rico. Based on follow-up survey data on teams that completed the course between 2013 and 2017, 167 teams had at least one team member report at least one patent application, and 147 of the teams had at least one team member report at least one granted patent. Data from the Pitchbook business database indicates 2,384 jobs are associated with businesses who participated in the I-Corps program.

During this award period, VentureWell has developed and is continuously optimizing a Public Use Dataset (PUDS) to make I-Corps data available to the broader research community. Dissemination of this data through PUDS, and resulting research utilizing PUDS, will inform program improvements, help define whether additional resources and support for program participants are needed, and advance understanding of factors that may influence the process of commercialization of academic research.

Learnings from I-Corps become lifelong tools that participating scientific and technical researchers can apply continually and teach others, maximizing the impact of their ideas on the economy and the world. Participants report that the I-Corps program has led them to think and do research differently, namely to be more sophisticated in determining the applications of their discoveries, seeking practical applications, conceptualizing startup opportunities, and having language and processes that enable them to successfully engage with industry and research partners. There is evidence that the program can increase an entrepreneurial mindset among participating post-doctoral students, graduate students, and undergraduate students. Through comprehensive evaluation of participant reflections, VentureWell has found that participants perceive the course as extremely valuable, often stating that the content and the process changed their thinking and approach to their research and its potential applications, as well as future work such as teaching, guiding start-ups, and their careers more generally.

Through this award, VentureWell supported the implementation and evaluation of teams in 36 national cohorts, including one faculty training and four all-SBIR cohorts. This award also supported VentureWell in taking significant steps towards evaluation and data system optimization for the I-Corps program, including data summary dashboard development and biennial public-use dataset releases. As the program grows, it is critical that program outcomes, pedagogy, and follow-on results are continuously evaluated in order to monitor and maintain the quality and consistency of the program. This award significantly contributed to VentureWell's ongoing efforts towards these goals.


 

 


Last Modified: 02/11/2022
Modified by: Philip J Weilerstein
